But deare Sir, give him leave that pre≈øumeth to ≈øay and that without flatery, he honoureth you as he doth his owne life and being, that looking as a dilligent ≈øpectator upon your actions and carriages, for this many moneths together, It hath ≈øtruck him into an ama≈øe, and filled his ≈øpirit as full of boylings and turmoylings as ever Jeremiahs was, when he ≈øaid thy word is within me like a burning fire, ≈øhut up in my bones, and I am weary with forbearing, and I could not ≈øtay Jer. 20.9. and truly Sir I was in paines and travell how to behave my ≈øelfe towards you, and faine I would have writ my minde freely and plainly unto you, but truly unto my owne ≈øhame I mu≈øt really acknowledge, I have been like Jonah who fled from the pre≈øence of God and the Errand he had to imploy him upon. Thou ≈øhalt not wre≈øt the judgement of the poore in his cau≈øe. Keep thee farre from a fal≈øe matter, and the innocent and the righteous ≈ølay thou not: For I will not ju≈øtifie the wicked. Thou ≈øhalt take no gift: for the gift blindeth the wi≈øe, and perverteth the words of the righteous. O deere Cromwell, the Lord open thy eyes, and make thy heart ≈øen≈øible of tho≈øe ≈ønares that are laid for thee in that vote of the Hou≈øe of Commons of two thou≈øand five hundred pounds per annum.

And Deut. 16.19. God ≈øaith expre≈øly, Thou ≈øhalt not wre≈øt judgement, thou ≈øhalt not re≈øpect per≈øons, neither take a gift: For a gift doth blind the eyes of the wi≈øe, and pervert the words of the righteous. And truly being very fearfull and jealous in my own ≈øoule, that ≈øome of my true friends, with whom I have talked of your ≈øelfe very freely of late, ≈øhould ≈øhortly hit me in the teeth by rea≈øon of my ≈øilence to you, and too ju≈øtly upbrayd me with that ≈øaying of Eccle≈øia≈øticus, chap. 20 ver≈ø, 29. Now deer Sir, knowing that you cannot but know, that it is a ≈øaying of the Spirit of God, That faithfull are the wounds of a Friend, but deceitfull are the k ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øes of an Enemy. I come now downright to unbowell my mind unto you and truly to tell you, that in my thoughts I look upon the redeemed ones of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt in England, in as low and ≈øad a condition, almo≈øt as the Iews were in the third of E≈øther, when Haman upon this fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion to K Ha≈øhuero≈øh, [That there is a certain people ≈øcattered abroad, and di≈øper≈øed among≈øt the people in all the provinces of the Kingdome, and their lawes are divers from all people, neither keep they the Kings lawes, therefore it is not for the Kings profit to ≈øuffer them] had obtained a Decree to de≈øtroy them all; and therefore as poore Mordicai in the bitterne≈ø≈øe of his ≈øpirit in the fourth chapter, ≈øayd unto Queen E≈øther, ≈øo ≈øay I to thee, thou great man Cromwell, Think not with thy≈øelf, that thou ≈øhalt e≈øcape in the Parliament Hou≈øe, more then all the re≈øt of the Lambs poore de≈øpi≈øed redeemed ones, and therefore, O Cromwell, if thou altogether holde≈øt thy peace, (or ≈øtoppe≈øt or undermine≈øt as thou do≈øt, our and the Armies petitions) at this time then ≈øhall enlargement and deliverance ari≈øe to us poore afflicted ones, (that have hithertoo doted too much upon thee, O Cromwell) from another place then from you ≈øilken Independents, the broken reeds of Egypt in the Hou≈øe and Army) but thou and thy Fathers Hou≈øe ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed: but who knoweth whether thou art come out of thy ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and to ≈øuch a height in the kingdome, for ≈øuch a time as this‚ñ™

And therefore if thou wilt pluck up thy re≈øolutions, like a man that will per≈øevere to be a man for God, and goe on bravely in the feare and name of God, and ≈øay with E≈øther, If I peri≈øh I peri≈øh; but if thou would not, know that here before God I arraigne thee at his dreadfull Barre, and there accu≈øe thee of delu≈øions and faire words, deceitfully, for betraying us, our wives and children into the Haman-like tyrannicall clutches of Ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is and Stapleton (both now impeached): and the re≈øt of that bloody and devouring faction, that hath de≈øigned us to utter ruine and de≈øtruction, and this land and kingdome to va≈ø≈øalage and ≈ølavery again≈øt whom we are ≈øufficiently able to per≈øevere our ≈øelves, if it were nor for thee, O Cromwell, that art led by the no≈øe by two unworthy covetous earthwormes, Vaine and St. Iohn (I mean young Sir Henry Vaine, and Sollicitor St. Iohn) who≈øe ba≈øene≈ø≈øe I ≈øufficiently anatomized unto thee in thy bed above a yeare agoe in Colonel Mountagues hou≈øe in the Pears, as thou can≈øt not but very well remember, and which I am re≈øolved to the purpo≈øe ≈øhortly to print.See the la≈øt page of the Outcries of the oppre≈ø≈øed Commons, and the Re≈øolved mans Re≈øolution. p. 6. 7, 8 9, 10.
